title: Build Caching Quiz
description: Test your understanding of Gradle build caching, incremental compilation, and optimization strategies.

questions.text: What does Gradle's build cache store?
options: Source code snapshots for version control
Task outputs keyed by task inputs, so identical inputs skip execution
Compiled classes only (not resources or generated files)
questions.explanation: Gradle's build cache stores the outputs of each task (compiled classes, processed resources, generated files) keyed by a hash of the task's inputs. When inputs match a cache entry, the outputs are restored instead of re-executing the task.

questions.text: What is the difference between a local build cache and a remote build cache?
options: Local caches use SSD, remote caches use HDD
Local cache is per-machine (in ~/.gradle); remote cache is shared across developers and CI via an HTTP server
Local cache is for debug builds; remote cache is for release builds
They are the same -- 'remote' just means a different directory
questions.explanation: The local build cache lives on your machine (~/.gradle/caches/build-cache-1/). A remote build cache is an HTTP server (Gradle Enterprise or custom) shared by all developers and CI agents. When CI builds populate the remote cache, developer machines benefit from pre-computed results.

questions.text: Why should you avoid using 'gradle clean build' as your default build command?
options: 'clean' deletes all build outputs, forcing full recompilation and defeating incremental compilation and caching
questions.explanation: 'gradle clean' deletes the entire build directory, destroying incremental compilation state and local build cache entries. This forces a full rebuild from scratch. Use 'gradle build' alone -- Gradle's up-to-date checks and caching handle invalidation automatically.
